  `position` BIGINT COMMENT 'The finishing position or track of circuits',
  `positionText` TEXT COMMENT 'not quite useful',
  `positionOrder` BIGINT COMMENT 'the finishing order of positions',
  `points` DOUBLE COMMENT 'points',
  `laps` BIGINT COMMENT 'lap number',
  `time` TEXT COMMENT 'finish time; commonsense evidence: 
1. if the value exists, it means the driver finished the race. 
2. Only the time of the champion shows in the format of "minutes: seconds.millionsecond", the time of the other drivers shows as "seconds.millionsecond" , which means their actual time is the time of the champion adding the value in this cell.',
  `milliseconds` BIGINT COMMENT 'the actual finishing time of drivers in milliseconds; the actual finishing time of drivers',
  `fastestLap` BIGINT COMMENT 'fastest lap number',
  `rank` BIGINT COMMENT 'starting rank positioned by fastest lap speed',
  `fastestLapTime` TEXT COMMENT 'fastest Lap Time; faster (smaller in the value) "fastestLapTime" leads to higher rank (smaller is higher rank)',
  `fastestLapSpeed` TEXT COMMENT 'fastest Lap Speed; (km / h)',
  `statusId` BIGINT COMMENT 'status ID; its category description appear in the table status'
);
CREATE TABLE `seasons` (
  `year` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying the race',
  `url` TEXT COMMENT 'website link of season race introduction'
);
CREATE TABLE `status` (
  `statusId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying status',
  `status` TEXT COMMENT 'full name of status'
);

SELECT
  `T1`.`time`
FROM `results` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `races` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`raceId` = `T2`.`raceId`
WHERE
  `T2`.`name` = 'Canadian Grand Prix'
  AND `T2`.`year` = 2008
  AND `T1`.`time` LIKE '_:%:__.___'
rejected:

  `T2`.`surname`,
  `T1`.`time`
FROM `results` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `drivers` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`driverId` = `T2`.`driverId`
INNER JOIN `races` AS `T3`
  ON `T1`.`raceId` = `T3`.`raceId`
WHERE
  `T3`.`name` = 'Canadian Grand Prix' AND `T3`.`year` = 2008 AND `T1`.`position` = 1

instruction: You are an expert data analyst. Please write a MySQL query that satisfies the requirement below.
input:
Please list all the superpowers of 3-D Man.
CREATE TABLE `alignment` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the alignment',
  `alignment` TEXT COMMENT 'the alignment of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.
	Bad: These superheroes are typically selfish, manipulative, and willing to harm others in pursuit of their own goals. Examples of evil alignments include Lex Luthor and the Joker.'
);
CREATE TABLE `attribute` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the attribute',
  `attribute_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute; commonsense evidence:
A superheros attribute is a characteristic or quality that defines who they are and what they are capable of. This could be a physical trait, such as superhuman strength or the ability to fly, or a personal trait, such as extraordinary intelligence or exceptional bravery.'
);
CREATE TABLE `colour` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the color',
  `colour` TEXT COMMENT 'the color of the superheros skin/eye/hair/etc'
);
CREATE TABLE `gender` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the gender',
  `gender` TEXT COMMENT 'the gender of the superhero'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_attribute` (
  `hero_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `attribute_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the attribute
Maps to attribute(id)',
  `attribute_value` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute value; commonsense evidence:
If a superhero has a higher attribute value on a particular attribute, it means that they are more skilled or powerful in that area compared to other superheroes. For example, if a superhero has a higher attribute value for strength, they may be able to lift heavier objects or deliver more powerful punches than other superheroes.'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_power` (
  `hero_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `power_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the power
Maps to superpower(id); commonsense evidence:
In general, a superheros attributes provide the foundation for their abilities and help to define who they are, while their powers are the specific abilities that they use to fight crime and protect others.'
);
CREATE TABLE `publisher` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the publisher',
  `publisher_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the publisher'
);
CREATE TABLE `race` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the race',
  `race` TEXT COMMENT 'the race of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
In the context of superheroes, a superheros race would refer to the particular group of people that the superhero belongs to base on these physical characteristics'
);
CREATE TABLE `superhero` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superhero',
  `superhero_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the superhero',
  `full_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the full name of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The full name of a person typically consists of their given name, also known as their first name or personal name, and their surname, also known as their last name or family name. For example, if someones given name is "John" and their surname is "Smith," their full name would be "John Smith."',
  `gender_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros gender',
  `eye_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros eye color',
  `hair_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros hair color',
  `skin_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros skin color',
  `race_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros race',
  `publisher_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the publisher',
  `alignment_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros alignment',
  `height_cm` BIGINT COMMENT 'the height of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of height is centimeter. If the height_cm is NULL or 0, it means the height of the superhero is missing.',
  `weight_kg` BIGINT COMMENT 'the weight of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of weight is kilogram. If the weight_kg is NULL or 0, it means the weight of the superhero is missing.'
);
CREATE TABLE `superpower` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superpower',
  `power_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the superpower name'
);
chosen: SELECT  `T3`.`power_name` FROM `superhero` AS `T1` INNER JOIN `hero_power` AS `T2`  ON `T1`.`id` = `T2`.`hero_id` INNER JOIN `superpower` AS `T3`  ON `T2`.`power_id` = `T3`.`id` WHERE  `T1`.`superhero_name` = '3-D Man'
rejected:
SELECT DISTINCT
  `T3`.`power_name`
FROM `superhero` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `hero_power` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`id` = `T2`.`hero_id`
INNER JOIN `superpower` AS `T3`
  ON `T2`.`power_id` = `T3`.`id`
WHERE
  `T1`.`superhero_name` = '3-D Man'

FROM `constructorResults` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `constructors` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`constructorId` = `T2`.`constructorId`
INNER JOIN `races` AS `T3`
  ON `T3`.`raceid` = `T1`.`raceid`
WHERE
  `T3`.`name` = 'Monaco Grand Prix' AND `T3`.`year` BETWEEN 1980 AND 2010
GROUP BY
  `T2`.`name`
ORDER BY

chosen:
SELECT
  `T2`.`forename`,
  `T2`.`surname`
FROM `qualifying` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `drivers` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`driverId` = `T2`.`driverId`
INNER JOIN `races` AS `T3`
  ON `T1`.`raceid` = `T3`.`raceid`
WHERE
  NOT `q3` IS NULL
  AND `T3`.`year` = 2008
  AND `T3`.`circuitId` IN (
    SELECT
      `circuitId`
    FROM `circuits`
    WHERE
      `name` = 'Marina Bay Street Circuit'
  )
ORDER BY
  CAST(SUBSTR(`q3`, 1, INSTR(`q3`, ':') - 1) AS SIGNED) * 60 + CAST(SUBSTR(`q3`, INSTR(`q3`, ':') + 1, INSTR(`q3`, '.') - INSTR(`q3`, ':') - 1) AS DOUBLE) + CAST(SUBSTR(`q3`, INSTR(`q3`, '.') + 1) AS DOUBLE) / 1000 ASC
LIMIT 1

  ON `T4`.`driverId` = `T1`.`driverId`

  `T3`.`name` = 'Marina Bay Street Circuit' AND `T2`.`year` = 2008 AND `T1`.`position` = 1

chosen: WITH lap_times_in_seconds AS (SELECT driverId, (CASE WHEN SUBSTR(time, 1, INSTR(time, ':') - 1) <> '' THEN CAST(SUBSTR(time, 1, INSTR(time, ':') - 1) AS FLOAT) * 60 ELSE 0 END + CASE WHEN SUBSTR(time, INSTR(time, ':') + 1, INSTR(time, '.') - INSTR(time, ':') - 1) <> '' THEN CAST(SUBSTR(time, INSTR(time, ':') + 1, INSTR(time, '.') - INSTR(time, ':') - 1) AS FLOAT) ELSE 0 END + CASE WHEN SUBSTR(time, INSTR(time, '.') + 1) <> '' THEN CAST(SUBSTR(time, INSTR(time, '.') + 1) AS FLOAT) / 1000 ELSE 0 END) AS time_in_seconds FROM lapTimes) SELECT T2.forename, T2.surname, T1.driverId FROM (SELECT driverId, MIN(time_in_seconds) AS min_time_in_seconds FROM lap_times_in_seconds GROUP BY driverId) AS T1 INNER JOIN drivers AS T2 ON T1.driverId = T2.driverId ORDER BY T1.min_time_in_seconds ASC LIMIT 20

chosen:
WITH `fastest_lap_times` AS (
  SELECT
    `T1`.`raceId`,
    `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
    (
      CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, 1, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1) AS DOUBLE) * 60
    ) + (
      CAST(SUBSTR(
        `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
        INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') + 1,
        INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') - INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1
      ) AS DOUBLE)
    ) + (
      CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') + 1) AS DOUBLE) / 1000
    ) AS `time_in_seconds`
  FROM `results` AS `T1`
  WHERE
    NOT `T1`.`FastestLapTime` IS NULL
)
SELECT
  `T1`.`FastestLapTime` AS `lap_record`
FROM `results` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `races` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`raceId` = `T2`.`raceId`
INNER JOIN `circuits` AS `T3`
  ON `T2`.`circuitId` = `T3`.`circuitId`
INNER JOIN (
  SELECT
    MIN(`fastest_lap_times`.`time_in_seconds`) AS `min_time_in_seconds`
  FROM `fastest_lap_times`
  INNER JOIN `races` AS `T2`
    ON `fastest_lap_times`.`raceId` = `T2`.`raceId`
  INNER JOIN `circuits` AS `T3`
    ON `T2`.`circuitId` = `T3`.`circuitId`
  WHERE
    `T3`.`country` = 'Italy'
) AS `T4`
  ON (
    CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, 1, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1) AS DOUBLE) * 60
  ) + (
    CAST(SUBSTR(
      `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
      INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') + 1,
      INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') - INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1
    ) AS DOUBLE)
  ) + (
    CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') + 1) AS DOUBLE) / 1000
  ) = `T4`.`min_time_in_seconds`
LIMIT 1

CREATE TABLE `alignment` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the alignment',
  `alignment` TEXT COMMENT 'the alignment of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.
	Bad: These superheroes are typically selfish, manipulative, and willing to harm others in pursuit of their own goals. Examples of evil alignments include Lex Luthor and the Joker.'
);
CREATE TABLE `attribute` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the attribute',
  `attribute_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute; commonsense evidence:
A superheros attribute is a characteristic or quality that defines who they are and what they are capable of. This could be a physical trait, such as superhuman strength or the ability to fly, or a personal trait, such as extraordinary intelligence or exceptional bravery.'
);
CREATE TABLE `colour` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the color',
  `colour` TEXT COMMENT 'the color of the superheros skin/eye/hair/etc'
);

  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the gender',
  `gender` TEXT COMMENT 'the gender of the superhero'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_attribute` (
  `hero_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `attribute_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the attribute
Maps to attribute(id)',
  `attribute_value` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute value; commonsense evidence:
If a superhero has a higher attribute value on a particular attribute, it means that they are more skilled or powerful in that area compared to other superheroes. For example, if a superhero has a higher attribute value for strength, they may be able to lift heavier objects or deliver more powerful punches than other superheroes.'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_power` (
  `hero_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `power_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the power
Maps to superpower(id); commonsense evidence:
In general, a superheros attributes provide the foundation for their abilities and help to define who they are, while their powers are the specific abilities that they use to fight crime and protect others.'
);
CREATE TABLE `publisher` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the publisher',
  `publisher_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the publisher'
);
CREATE TABLE `race` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the race',
  `race` TEXT COMMENT 'the race of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
In the context of superheroes, a superheros race would refer to the particular group of people that the superhero belongs to base on these physical characteristics'
);
CREATE TABLE `superhero` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superhero',
  `superhero_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the superhero',
  `full_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the full name of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The full name of a person typically consists of their given name, also known as their first name or personal name, and their surname, also known as their last name or family name. For example, if someones given name is "John" and their surname is "Smith," their full name would be "John Smith."',
  `gender_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros gender',
  `eye_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros eye color',
  `hair_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros hair color',
  `skin_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros skin color',
  `race_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros race',
  `publisher_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the publisher',
  `alignment_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros alignment',
  `height_cm` BIGINT COMMENT 'the height of the superhero; commonsense evidence:

input:
Which user has a higher reputation, Harlan or Jarrod Dixon?
CREATE TABLE `badges` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the badge id',

  `Date` TEXT COMMENT 'the date that the user obtained the badge'
);
CREATE TABLE `comments` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the comment Id',
  `PostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique id of the post',
  `Score` BIGINT COMMENT 'rating score; commonsense evidence:
The score is from 0 to 100. The score more than 60 refers that the comment is a positive comment. The score less than 60 refers that the comment is a negative comment.',
  `Text` TEXT COMMENT 'the detailed content of the comment',
  `CreationDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the creation date of the comment',
  `UserId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the user who post the comment',
  `UserDisplayName` TEXT COMMENT 'users display name'
);
CREATE TABLE `postHistory` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the post history id',
  `PostHistoryTypeId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the post history type',
  `PostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique id of the post',
  `RevisionGUID` BIGINT COMMENT 'the revision globally unique id of the post',
  `CreationDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the creation date of the post',
  `UserId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the user who post the post',
  `Text` TEXT COMMENT 'the detailed content of the post',
  `Comment` TEXT COMMENT 'comments of the post',
  `UserDisplayName` TEXT COMMENT 'users display name'
);
CREATE TABLE `postLinks` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the post link id',
  `CreationDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the creation date of the post link',
  `PostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the post id',
  `RelatedPostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the related post',
  `LinkTypeId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the link type'
);
CREATE TABLE `posts` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the post id',
  `PostTypeId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the post type',
  `AcceptedAnswerId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the accepted answer id of the post',
  `CreaionDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the creation date of the post',
  `Score` BIGINT COMMENT 'the score of the post',
  `ViewCount` BIGINT COMMENT 'the view count of the post; commonsense evidence:
Higher view count means the post has higher popularity',
  `Body` TEXT COMMENT 'the body of the post',
  `OwnerUserId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the owner user',
  `LasActivityDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the last activity date',
  `Title` TEXT COMMENT 'the title of the post',
  `Tags` TEXT COMMENT 'the tag of the post',
  `AnswerCount` BIGINT COMMENT 'the total number of answers of the post',
  `CommentCount` BIGINT COMMENT 'the total number of comments of the post',
  `FavoriteCount` BIGINT COMMENT 'the total number of favorites of the post; commonsense evidence:
more favorite count refers to more valuable posts.',
  `LastEditorUserId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the last editor',
  `LastEditDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the last edit date',
  `CommunityOwnedDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the community owned date',
  `ParentId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the parent post; commonsense evidence:
If the parent id is null, the post is the root post. Otherwise, the post is the child post of other post.',
  `ClosedDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the closed date of the post; commonsense evidence:
if ClosedDate is null or empty, it means this post is not well-finished
if CloseDate is not null or empty, it means this post has well-finished.',
  `OwnerDisplayName` TEXT COMMENT 'the display name of the post owner',
  `LastEditorDisplayName` TEXT COMMENT 'the display name of the last editor'
);
CREATE TABLE `tags` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the tag id',
  `TagName` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the tag',
  `Count` BIGINT COMMENT 'the count of posts that contain this tag; more counts --> this tag is more popular',
  `ExcerptPostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the excerpt post id of the tag',
  `WikiPostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the wiki post id of the tag'
);
CREATE TABLE `users` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the user id',
  `Reputation` BIGINT COMMENT 'the users reputation; commonsense evidence:
The user with higher reputation has more influence.',
  `CreationDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the creation date of the user account',
  `DisplayName` TEXT COMMENT 'the users display name',
  `LastAccessDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the last access date of the user account',
  `WebsiteUrl` TEXT COMMENT 'the website url of the user account',
  `Location` TEXT COMMENT 'users location',
  `AboutMe` TEXT COMMENT 'the self introduction of the user',
  `Views` BIGINT COMMENT 'the number of views',
  `UpVotes` BIGINT COMMENT 'the number of upvotes',
  `DownVotes` BIGINT COMMENT 'the number of downvotes',
  `AccountId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique id of the account',
  `Age` BIGINT COMMENT 'users age;  teenager: 13-18
 adult: 19-65
 elder: > 65',
  `ProfileImageUrl` TEXT COMMENT 'the profile image url'
);
CREATE TABLE `votes` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the vote id',
  `PostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the post that is voted',
  `VoteTypeId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the vote type',
  `CreationDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the creation date of the vote',
  `UserId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the voter',
  `BountyAmount` BIGINT COMMENT 'the amount of bounty'
);
chosen:
SELECT
  `DisplayName`
FROM `users`
WHERE
  `DisplayName` IN ('Harlan', 'Jarrod Dixon')
  AND `Reputation` = (
    SELECT
      MAX(`Reputation`)
    FROM `users`
    WHERE
      `DisplayName` IN ('Harlan', 'Jarrod Dixon')
  )

INNER JOIN `posts` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`Id` = `T2`.`OwnerUserId`
WHERE
  `T1`.`Id` = 24
GROUP BY

Which user have only one post history per post and having at least 1000 views?
CREATE TABLE `badges` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the badge id',
  `UserId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique id of the user',
  `Name` TEXT COMMENT 'the badge name the user obtained',
  `Date` TEXT COMMENT 'the date that the user obtained the badge'
);
CREATE TABLE `comments` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the comment Id',
  `PostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique id of the post',
  `Score` BIGINT COMMENT 'rating score; commonsense evidence:
The score is from 0 to 100. The score more than 60 refers that the comment is a positive comment. The score less than 60 refers that the comment is a negative comment.',
  `Text` TEXT COMMENT 'the detailed content of the comment',
  `CreationDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the creation date of the comment',
  `UserId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the user who post the comment',
  `UserDisplayName` TEXT COMMENT 'users display name'
);
CREATE TABLE `postHistory` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the post history id',
  `PostHistoryTypeId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the post history type',
  `PostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique id of the post',
  `RevisionGUID` BIGINT COMMENT 'the revision globally unique id of the post',
  `CreationDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the creation date of the post',
  `UserId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the user who post the post',
  `Text` TEXT COMMENT 'the detailed content of the post',
  `Comment` TEXT COMMENT 'comments of the post',
  `UserDisplayName` TEXT COMMENT 'users display name'
);
CREATE TABLE `postLinks` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the post link id',
  `CreationDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the creation date of the post link',
  `PostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the post id',
  `RelatedPostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the related post',
  `LinkTypeId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the link type'
);
CREATE TABLE `posts` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the post id',
  `PostTypeId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the post type',
  `AcceptedAnswerId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the accepted answer id of the post',
  `CreaionDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the creation date of the post',
  `Score` BIGINT COMMENT 'the score of the post',
  `ViewCount` BIGINT COMMENT 'the view count of the post; commonsense evidence:
Higher view count means the post has higher popularity',
  `Body` TEXT COMMENT 'the body of the post',
  `OwnerUserId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the owner user',
  `LasActivityDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the last activity date',
  `Title` TEXT COMMENT 'the title of the post',
  `Tags` TEXT COMMENT 'the tag of the post',
  `AnswerCount` BIGINT COMMENT 'the total number of answers of the post',
  `CommentCount` BIGINT COMMENT 'the total number of comments of the post',
  `FavoriteCount` BIGINT COMMENT 'the total number of favorites of the post; commonsense evidence:
more favorite count refers to more valuable posts.',
  `LastEditorUserId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the last editor',
  `LastEditDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the last edit date',
  `CommunityOwnedDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the community owned date',
  `ParentId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the parent post; commonsense evidence:
If the parent id is null, the post is the root post. Otherwise, the post is the child post of other post.',
  `ClosedDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the closed date of the post; commonsense evidence:
if ClosedDate is null or empty, it means this post is not well-finished
if CloseDate is not null or empty, it means this post has well-finished.',
  `OwnerDisplayName` TEXT COMMENT 'the display name of the post owner',
  `LastEditorDisplayName` TEXT COMMENT 'the display name of the last editor'
);
CREATE TABLE `tags` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the tag id',
  `TagName` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the tag',
  `Count` BIGINT COMMENT 'the count of posts that contain this tag; more counts --> this tag is more popular',
  `ExcerptPostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the excerpt post id of the tag',
  `WikiPostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the wiki post id of the tag'
);
CREATE TABLE `users` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the user id',
  `Reputation` BIGINT COMMENT 'the users reputation; commonsense evidence:
The user with higher reputation has more influence.',
  `CreationDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the creation date of the user account',
  `DisplayName` TEXT COMMENT 'the users display name',
  `LastAccessDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the last access date of the user account',
  `WebsiteUrl` TEXT COMMENT 'the website url of the user account',
  `Location` TEXT COMMENT 'users location',
  `AboutMe` TEXT COMMENT 'the self introduction of the user',
  `Views` BIGINT COMMENT 'the number of views',
  `UpVotes` BIGINT COMMENT 'the number of upvotes',
  `DownVotes` BIGINT COMMENT 'the number of downvotes',
  `AccountId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique id of the account',
  `Age` BIGINT COMMENT 'users age;  teenager: 13-18
 adult: 19-65
 elder: > 65',
  `ProfileImageUrl` TEXT COMMENT 'the profile image url'
);
CREATE TABLE `votes` (
  `Id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the vote id',
  `PostId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the post that is voted',
  `VoteTypeId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the vote type',
  `CreationDate` TEXT COMMENT 'the creation date of the vote',
  `UserId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the voter',
  `BountyAmount` BIGINT COMMENT 'the amount of bounty'
);
chosen:
SELECT
  `T2`.`UserId`
FROM `users` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `postHistory` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`Id` = `T2`.`UserId`
INNER JOIN `posts` AS `T3`
  ON `T2`.`PostId` = `T3`.`Id`
WHERE
  `T3`.`ViewCount` >= 1000
GROUP BY
  `T2`.`UserId`
HAVING
  COUNT(DISTINCT `T2`.`PostHistoryTypeId`) = 1
rejected:
SELECT
  `T2`.`UserId`
FROM `postHistory` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `posts` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`PostId` = `T2`.`Id`
WHERE
  `T2`.`ViewCount` >= 1000
GROUP BY
  `T2`.`UserId`
HAVING
  COUNT(DISTINCT `T1`.`PostHistoryTypeId`) = 1

SELECT
  AVG(`T1`.`UpVotes`),
  AVG(`T1`.`Age`)
FROM `users` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN (
  SELECT
    `OwnerUserId`,
    COUNT(*) AS `post_count`
  FROM `posts`
  GROUP BY
    `OwnerUserId`
  HAVING
    `post_count` > 10
) AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`Id` = `T2`.`OwnerUserId`

GROUP BY
  `T2`.`Id`
HAVING
  COUNT(`T1`.`Id`) > 10

SELECT

INNER JOIN `posts` AS `T2`

WHERE
  `T2`.`status` = 'Legal'
  AND `T2`.`format` = 'commander'
  AND (
    `T1`.`power` IS NULL OR `T1`.`power` = '*'

WHERE
  `T2`.`format` = 'commander' AND `T2`.`status` = 'Legal' AND `T1`.`power` IS NULL

chosen: SELECT `T1`.`name`, `T1`.`artist`, `T1`.`isPromo` FROM `cards` AS `T1` INNER JOIN `rulings` AS `T2` ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T2`.`uuid` WHERE `T1`.`isPromo` = 1 AND `T1`.`artist` = ( SELECT `artist` FROM `cards` WHERE `isPromo` = 1 GROUP BY `artist` HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT `uuid`) = (SELECT MAX(card_counts.max_count) FROM (SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT `uuid`) AS max_count FROM `cards` WHERE `isPromo` = 1 GROUP BY `artist`) AS card_counts))LIMIT 1
rejected:
SELECT
  `T1`.`name`,
  `T1`.`artist`,
  CASE WHEN `T1`.`isPromo` = 1 THEN 'Yes' ELSE 'No' END AS `isPromo`
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `rulings` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T2`.`uuid`
ORDER BY
  COUNT(`T2`.`id`) DESC
LIMIT 1

  ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T2`.`uuid`

chosen:
SELECT
  `T2`.`format`
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `legalities` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T2`.`uuid`
WHERE
  `T1`.`name` = 'Benalish Knight'

SELECT
  `T1`.`format`
FROM `legalities` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `cards` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T2`.`uuid`
WHERE
  `T2`.`name` = 'Benalish Knight' AND `T1`.`status` = 'Legal'

SELECT
  CAST(SUM(CASE WHEN `T2`.`language` = 'French' THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) AS DOUBLE) * 100 / COUNT(`T1`.`id`)
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `foreign_data` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T2`.`uuid`
WHERE
  `T1`.`isStorySpotlight` = 1

WHERE
  `T1`.`isStorySpotlight` = 1

chosen:
SELECT
  COUNT(`T1`.`id`)
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `legalities` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T2`.`uuid`
WHERE
  `T2`.`status` = 'Banned' AND `T1`.`borderColor` = 'white'
rejected:
SELECT
  COUNT(`T1`.`id`)
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `legalities` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T2`.`uuid`
WHERE
  `T2`.`status` = 'Banned' AND `T1`.`borderColor` = 'white'

chosen:
SELECT
  COUNT(`T1`.`id`)
FROM `sets` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `set_translations` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`code` = `T2`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`language` = 'Portuguese (Brazil)' AND `T1`.`block` = 'Commander'

WHERE
  `T2`.`language` = 'Portuguese (Brazil)' AND `T1`.`block` = 'Commander'

  Count(DISTINCT `T1`.`id`) 
FROM `cards` AS `T1`

  ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T2`.`uuid`
WHERE

    `T1`.`power` IS NULL OR `T1`.`power` = '*'
  )
  AND `T2`.`text` LIKE '%triggered ability%'

  COUNT(`T1`.`id`)
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `legalities` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T2`.`uuid`
INNER JOIN `rulings` AS `T3`
  ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T3`.`uuid`
WHERE

SELECT
  `name`
FROM `foreign_data`
WHERE
  `uuid` IN (
    SELECT
      `uuid`
    FROM `cards`
    WHERE
      `types` = 'Creature'
      AND `layout` = 'normal'
      AND `borderColor` = 'black'
      AND `artist` = 'Matthew D. Wilson'
  )
  AND `language` = 'French'
rejected:
SELECT DISTINCT
  `T2`.`name`
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `foreign_data` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`uuid` = `T1`.`uuid`
WHERE
  `T2`.`language` = 'French' AND `T1`.`type` = 'Creature' AND `T1`.`layout` = 'normal' AND `T1`.`borderColor` = 'black' AND `T1`.`artist` = 'Matthew D. Wilson'

chosen:
SELECT
  `T2`.`language`
FROM `sets` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `set_translations` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`code` = `T2`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T1`.`mcmName` = 'Archenemy' AND `T2`.`setCode` = 'ARC'

SELECT DISTINCT
  `T2`.`language`
FROM `sets` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `set_translations` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`code` = `T2`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T1`.`type` = 'archenemy' AND `T2`.`setCode` = 'ARC'

  `name`
FROM `cards`
WHERE
  `name` IN ('Serra Angel', 'Shrine Keeper')
ORDER BY
  `convertedManaCost` DESC
LIMIT 1

  `type` TEXT COMMENT 'The expansion type of the set.; "alchemy", "archenemy", "arsenal", "box", "commander", "core", "draft_innovation", "duel_deck", "expansion", "from_the_vault", "funny", "masterpiece", "masters", "memorabilia", "planechase", "premium_deck", "promo", "spellbook", "starter", "token", "treasure_chest", "vanguard"'

chosen:
SELECT
  CASE
    WHEN SUM(
      CASE
        WHEN `T2`.`language` = 'Korean' AND NOT `T2`.`translation` IS NULL
        THEN 1
        ELSE 0
      END
    ) > 0
    THEN 'YES'
    ELSE 'NO'
  END
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `set_translations` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`setCode` = `T1`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T1`.`name` = 'Ancestor''s Chosen'
rejected:
SELECT
  CASE
    WHEN COUNT(`T1`.`id`) > 0
    THEN 'YES'
    ELSE 'NO'
  END
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `foreign_data` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T2`.`uuid`
WHERE
  `T1`.`name` = 'Ancestor''s Chosen' AND `T2`.`language` = 'Korean'

SELECT
  COUNT(`T1`.`id`)
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `set_translations` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`setCode` = `T1`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`translation` = 'Hauptset Zehnte Edition' AND `T1`.`artist` = 'Adam Rex'

  `T2`.`name` = 'Hauptset Zehnte Edition' AND `T1`.`artist` = 'Adam Rex'

SELECT
  `T2`.`translation`
FROM `sets` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `set_translations` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`setCode` = `T1`.`code`
WHERE
  `T1`.`name` = 'Eighth Edition' AND `T2`.`language` = 'Chinese Simplified'

chosen:
SELECT
  CASE WHEN NOT `T2`.`mtgoCode` IS NULL THEN 'YES' ELSE 'NO' END
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `sets` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`code` = `T1`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T1`.`name` = 'Angel of Mercy'
rejected:
SELECT
  CASE WHEN `T1`.`mtgoCode` IS NULL OR `T1`.`mtgoCode` = ''
  THEN 'No'
  ELSE 'Yes' END
FROM `sets` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `cards` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`setCode` = `T1`.`code`
WHERE
  `T2`.`name` = 'Angel of Mercy'

chosen:
SELECT
  COUNT(DISTINCT `T1`.`id`)
FROM `sets` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `set_translations` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`setCode` = `T1`.`code`
WHERE
  `T1`.`block` = 'Ice Age'
  AND `T2`.`language` = 'Italian'
  AND NOT `T2`.`translation` IS NULL
rejected:
SELECT
  COUNT(`T1`.`id`)
FROM `sets` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `set_translations` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`code` = `T2`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T1`.`block` = 'Ice Age' AND `T2`.`language` = 'Italian'

SELECT
  CASE WHEN `isForeignOnly` = 1 THEN 'YES' ELSE 'NO' END
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `sets` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`code` = `T1`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T1`.`name` = 'Adarkar Valkyrie'
rejected:
SELECT
  CASE WHEN NOT `T1`.`isForeignOnly` = 0 THEN 'Yes' ELSE 'No' END
FROM `sets` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `cards` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`setCode` = `T1`.`code`
WHERE
  `T2`.`name` = 'Adarkar Valkyrie'

chosen:
SELECT
  COUNT(`T1`.`id`)
FROM `sets` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `set_translations` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`setCode` = `T1`.`code`
WHERE
  NOT `T2`.`translation` IS NULL
  AND `T1`.`baseSetSize` < 100
  AND `T2`.`language` = 'Italian'
rejected:
SELECT
  COUNT(`T1`.`id`)
FROM `sets` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `set_translations` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`setCode` = `T1`.`code`
WHERE
  `T2`.`language` = 'Italian' AND `T1`.`baseSetSize` < 100

chosen:
SELECT
  `T1`.`artist`
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `sets` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`code` = `T1`.`setCode`
WHERE
  (
    `T2`.`name` = 'Coldsnap' AND `T1`.`artist` = 'Chippy'
  )
  OR (
    `T2`.`name` = 'Coldsnap' AND `T1`.`artist` = 'Aaron Miller'
  )
  OR (
    `T2`.`name` = 'Coldsnap' AND `T1`.`artist` = 'Jeremy Jarvis'
  )
GROUP BY
  `T1`.`artist`
rejected:

  `T1`.`artist`
FROM `cards` AS `T1`

  ON `T2`.`code` = `T1`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`name` = 'Coldsnap' AND `T1`.`artist` IN ('Jeremy Jarvis', 'Aaron Miller', 'Chippy')

chosen:
SELECT
  SUM(CASE WHEN `T1`.`power` = '*' OR `T1`.`power` IS NULL THEN 1 ELSE 0 END)
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `sets` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`code` = `T1`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`name` = 'Coldsnap' AND `T1`.`convertedManaCost` > 5
rejected:

FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `sets` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`code` = `T1`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`name` = 'Coldsnap' AND `T1`.`convertedManaCost` > 5 AND `T1`.`power` IS NULL

SELECT DISTINCT
  `T1`.`text`
FROM `foreign_data` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `cards` AS `T2`

INNER JOIN `sets` AS `T3`
  ON `T3`.`code` = `T2`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T3`.`name` = 'Coldsnap' AND `T1`.`language` = 'Italian'

chosen:
SELECT
  `T2`.`name`
FROM `foreign_data` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `cards` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`uuid` = `T1`.`uuid`
INNER JOIN `sets` AS `T3`
  ON `T3`.`code` = `T2`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T3`.`name` = 'Coldsnap' AND `T1`.`language` = 'Italian'
ORDER BY
  `T2`.`convertedManaCost` DESC
rejected:
SELECT DISTINCT
  `T2`.`name`
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `foreign_data` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T2`.`uuid`
INNER JOIN `set_translations` AS `T3`
  ON `T1`.`setCode` = `T3`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T3`.`translation` = 'Coldsnap' AND `T2`.`language` = 'Italian' AND `T1`.`convertedManaCost` = (
    SELECT
      MAX(`T1`.`convertedManaCost`)
    FROM `cards` AS `T1`
    INNER JOIN `set_translations` AS `T3`
      ON `T1`.`setCode` = `T3`.`setCode`
    WHERE
      `T3`.`translation` = 'Coldsnap'
  )

SELECT
  CAST(SUM(CASE WHEN `T1`.`convertedManaCost` = 7 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) AS DOUBLE) * 100 / COUNT(`T1`.`id`)
FROM `cards` AS `T1`

  ON `T2`.`code` = `T1`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`name` = 'Coldsnap'

chosen:
SELECT
  CAST(SUM(
    CASE
      WHEN NOT `T1`.`cardKingdomFoilId` IS NULL AND NOT `T1`.`cardKingdomId` IS NULL
      THEN 1
      ELSE 0
    END
  ) AS DOUBLE) * 100 / COUNT(`T1`.`id`)
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `sets` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`code` = `T1`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`name` = 'Coldsnap'
rejected:

FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `sets` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`code` = `T1`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`name` = 'Coldsnap'

chosen: SELECT T2.format, T1.name FROM cards AS T1 INNER JOIN legalities AS T2 ON T2.uuid = T1.uuid INNER JOIN ( SELECT format FROM legalities WHERE status = 'Banned' GROUP BY format ORDER BY COUNT(*) DESC LIMIT 1 ) AS MaxBanned ON MaxBanned.format = T2.format WHERE T2.status = 'Banned'
rejected:
SELECT
  `T1`.`format`,
  `T2`.`name`
FROM `legalities` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `cards` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`uuid` = `T1`.`uuid`
WHERE
  `T1`.`status` = 'Banned'
GROUP BY
  `T1`.`format`
ORDER BY
  COUNT(`T2`.`name`) DESC
LIMIT 1

SELECT
  `T1`.`name`,
  `T2`.`format`
FROM `cards` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `legalities` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`uuid` = `T1`.`uuid`
WHERE
  `T1`.`edhrecRank` = 1 AND `T2`.`status` = 'Banned'
GROUP BY
  `T1`.`name`,
  `T2`.`format`

  `type` TEXT COMMENT 'The expansion type of the set.; "alchemy", "archenemy", "arsenal", "box", "commander", "core", "draft_innovation", "duel_deck", "expansion", "from_the_vault", "funny", "masterpiece", "masters", "memorabilia", "planechase", "premium_deck", "promo", "spellbook", "starter", "token", "treasure_chest", "vanguard"'

chosen:
SELECT DISTINCT
  `T2`.`name`,
  CASE WHEN `T1`.`status` = 'Legal' THEN `T1`.`format` ELSE NULL END
FROM `legalities` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `cards` AS `T2`
  ON `T2`.`uuid` = `T1`.`uuid`
WHERE
  `T2`.`setCode` IN (
    SELECT
      `code`
    FROM `sets`
    WHERE
      `name` = 'Hour of Devastation'
  )
rejected:

  ON `T1`.`uuid` = `T2`.`uuid`
WHERE
  `T1`.`setCode` IN (
    SELECT
      `code`
    FROM `sets`
    WHERE
      `name` = 'Hour of Devastation'
  )

chosen:
SELECT
  `name`
FROM `sets`
WHERE
  `code` IN (
    SELECT
      `setCode`
    FROM `set_translations`
    WHERE
      `language` = 'Korean' AND NOT `language` LIKE '%Japanese%'
  )
rejected:
SELECT DISTINCT
  `T1`.`name`
FROM `sets` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `set_translations` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`code` = `T2`.`setCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`language` = 'Korean' AND NOT EXISTS (
    SELECT 1
    FROM `set_translations` AS `T3`
    WHERE
      `T3`.`setCode` = `T1`.`code` AND `T3`.`language` = 'Japanese'
  )

instruction: You are an expert data analyst. Please write a MySQL query that satisfies the requirement below.
input:
What is the most common bond type?
CREATE TABLE `atom` (
  `atom_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the unique id of atoms',
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'identifying the molecule to which the atom belongs; commonsense evidence:
TRXXX_i represents ith atom of molecule TRXXX',
  `element` TEXT COMMENT 'the element of the toxicology;  cl: chlorine
 c: carbon
 h: hydrogen
 o: oxygen
 s: sulfur
 n: nitrogen
 p: phosphorus
 na: sodium
 br: bromine
 f: fluorine
 i: iodine
 sn: Tin
 pb: lead
 te: tellurium
 ca: Calcium'
);
CREATE TABLE `bond` (
  `bond_id` TEXT COMMENT 'unique id representing bonds; TRxxx_A1_A2:
TRXXX refers to which molecule
A1 and A2 refers to which atom',
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'identifying the molecule in which the bond appears',
  `bond_type` TEXT COMMENT 'type of the bond; commonsense evidence:
-: single bond
=: double bond
#: triple bond'
);
CREATE TABLE `connected` (
  `atom_id` TEXT COMMENT 'id of the first atom',
  `atom_id2` TEXT COMMENT 'id of the second atom',
  `bond_id` TEXT COMMENT 'bond id representing bond between two atoms'
);
CREATE TABLE `molecule` (
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'unique id of molecule; "+" --> this molecule / compound is carcinogenic
- this molecule is not / compound carcinogenic',
  `label` TEXT COMMENT 'whether this molecule is carcinogenic or not'
);
chosen:
SELECT
  `T`.`bond_type`
FROM (
  SELECT
    `bond_type`,
    COUNT(`bond_id`)
  FROM `bond`
  GROUP BY
    `bond_type`
  ORDER BY
    COUNT(`bond_id`) DESC
  LIMIT 1
) AS `T`
rejected:
SELECT
  `T`.`bond_type`
FROM (
  SELECT
    `bond_type`,
    COUNT(`bond_id`) AS `cnt`
  FROM `bond`
  GROUP BY
    `bond_type`
  ORDER BY
    `cnt` DESC
  LIMIT 1
) AS `T`

instruction: You are an expert data analyst. Please write a MySQL query that satisfies the requirement below.
input:
Calculate the average number of oxygen atoms in single-bonded molecules.
CREATE TABLE `atom` (
  `atom_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the unique id of atoms',
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'identifying the molecule to which the atom belongs; commonsense evidence:
TRXXX_i represents ith atom of molecule TRXXX',
  `element` TEXT COMMENT 'the element of the toxicology;  cl: chlorine
 c: carbon
 h: hydrogen
 o: oxygen
 s: sulfur
 n: nitrogen
 p: phosphorus
 na: sodium
 br: bromine
 f: fluorine
 i: iodine
 sn: Tin
 pb: lead
 te: tellurium
 ca: Calcium'
);
CREATE TABLE `bond` (
  `bond_id` TEXT COMMENT 'unique id representing bonds; TRxxx_A1_A2:
TRXXX refers to which molecule
A1 and A2 refers to which atom',
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'identifying the molecule in which the bond appears',
  `bond_type` TEXT COMMENT 'type of the bond; commonsense evidence:
-: single bond
=: double bond
#: triple bond'
);
CREATE TABLE `connected` (
  `atom_id` TEXT COMMENT 'id of the first atom',
  `atom_id2` TEXT COMMENT 'id of the second atom',
  `bond_id` TEXT COMMENT 'bond id representing bond between two atoms'
);
CREATE TABLE `molecule` (
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'unique id of molecule; "+" --> this molecule / compound is carcinogenic
- this molecule is not / compound carcinogenic',
  `label` TEXT COMMENT 'whether this molecule is carcinogenic or not'
);
chosen:
SELECT
  AVG(`oxygen_count`)
FROM (
  SELECT
    `T1`.`molecule_id`,
    COUNT(`T1`.`element`) AS `oxygen_count`
  FROM `atom` AS `T1`
  INNER JOIN `bond` AS `T2`
    ON `T1`.`molecule_id` = `T2`.`molecule_id`
  WHERE
    `T2`.`bond_type` = '-' AND `T1`.`element` = 'o'
  GROUP BY
    `T1`.`molecule_id`
) AS `oxygen_counts`
rejected:
SELECT
  CAST(SUM(CASE WHEN `T1`.`element` = 'o' THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) AS DOUBLE) / COUNT(`T1`.`molecule_id`)
FROM `atom` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `bond` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`molecule_id` = `T2`.`molecule_id`
WHERE
  `T2`.`bond_type` = '-'

instruction: You are an expert data analyst. Please write a MySQL query that satisfies the requirement below.
input:
On average how many carcinogenic molecules are single bonded?
CREATE TABLE `atom` (
  `atom_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the unique id of atoms',
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'identifying the molecule to which the atom belongs; commonsense evidence:
TRXXX_i represents ith atom of molecule TRXXX',
  `element` TEXT COMMENT 'the element of the toxicology;  cl: chlorine
 c: carbon
 h: hydrogen
 o: oxygen
 s: sulfur
 n: nitrogen
 p: phosphorus
 na: sodium
 br: bromine
 f: fluorine
 i: iodine
 sn: Tin
 pb: lead
 te: tellurium
 ca: Calcium'
);
CREATE TABLE `bond` (
  `bond_id` TEXT COMMENT 'unique id representing bonds; TRxxx_A1_A2:
TRXXX refers to which molecule
A1 and A2 refers to which atom',
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'identifying the molecule in which the bond appears',
  `bond_type` TEXT COMMENT 'type of the bond; commonsense evidence:
-: single bond
=: double bond
#: triple bond'
);
CREATE TABLE `connected` (
  `atom_id` TEXT COMMENT 'id of the first atom',
  `atom_id2` TEXT COMMENT 'id of the second atom',
  `bond_id` TEXT COMMENT 'bond id representing bond between two atoms'
);
CREATE TABLE `molecule` (
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'unique id of molecule; "+" --> this molecule / compound is carcinogenic
- this molecule is not / compound carcinogenic',
  `label` TEXT COMMENT 'whether this molecule is carcinogenic or not'
);
chosen:
SELECT
  AVG(`single_bond_count`)
FROM (
  SELECT
    `T3`.`molecule_id`,
    COUNT(`T1`.`bond_type`) AS `single_bond_count`
  FROM `bond` AS `T1`
  INNER JOIN `atom` AS `T2`
    ON `T1`.`molecule_id` = `T2`.`molecule_id`
  INNER JOIN `molecule` AS `T3`
    ON `T3`.`molecule_id` = `T2`.`molecule_id`
  WHERE
    `T1`.`bond_type` = '-' AND `T3`.`label` = '+'
  GROUP BY
    `T3`.`molecule_id`
) AS `subquery`
rejected:
SELECT
  AVG(`T`.`single_bond_count`)
FROM (
  SELECT
    `T1`.`molecule_id`,
    COUNT(`T2`.`bond_id`) AS `single_bond_count`
  FROM `molecule` AS `T1`
  INNER JOIN `bond` AS `T2`
    ON `T1`.`molecule_id` = `T2`.`molecule_id`
  WHERE
    `T1`.`label` = '+' AND `T2`.`bond_type` = '-'
  GROUP BY
    `T1`.`molecule_id`
) AS `T`

CREATE TABLE `atom` (

TRXXX_i represents ith atom of molecule TRXXX',

 ca: Calcium'
);

  `bond_id` TEXT COMMENT 'unique id representing bonds; TRxxx_A1_A2:
TRXXX refers to which molecule
A1 and A2 refers to which atom',
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'identifying the molecule in which the bond appears',
  `bond_type` TEXT COMMENT 'type of the bond; commonsense evidence:
-: single bond
=: double bond
#: triple bond'
);

);

- this molecule is not / compound carcinogenic',
  `label` TEXT COMMENT 'whether this molecule is carcinogenic or not'

FROM `bond` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `molecule` AS `T2`

  `T1`.`bond_type` = '-'

instruction: You are an expert data analyst. Please write a MySQL query that satisfies the requirement below.
input:

CREATE TABLE `atom` (

  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'identifying the molecule to which the atom belongs; commonsense evidence:
TRXXX_i represents ith atom of molecule TRXXX',

 na: sodium
 br: bromine
 f: fluorine
 i: iodine
 sn: Tin
 pb: lead
 te: tellurium
 ca: Calcium'
);
CREATE TABLE `bond` (
  `bond_id` TEXT COMMENT 'unique id representing bonds; TRxxx_A1_A2:
TRXXX refers to which molecule
A1 and A2 refers to which atom',
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'identifying the molecule in which the bond appears',
  `bond_type` TEXT COMMENT 'type of the bond; commonsense evidence:
-: single bond
=: double bond
#: triple bond'
);

- this molecule is not / compound carcinogenic',
  `label` TEXT COMMENT 'whether this molecule is carcinogenic or not'
);
chosen:
SELECT
  CAST(COUNT(CASE WHEN `T`.`element` = 'cl' THEN `T`.`atom_id` ELSE NULL END) AS DOUBLE) * 100 / COUNT(`T`.`atom_id`)
FROM (
  SELECT
    `T1`.`atom_id`,
    `T1`.`element`
  FROM `atom` AS `T1`
  INNER JOIN `molecule` AS `T2`
    ON `T1`.`molecule_id` = `T2`.`molecule_id`
  INNER JOIN `bond` AS `T3`
    ON `T2`.`molecule_id` = `T3`.`molecule_id`
  WHERE
    `T3`.`bond_type` = '-'
) AS `T`

    `T1`.`atom_id`,
    `T1`.`element`

instruction: You are an expert data analyst. Please write a MySQL query that satisfies the requirement below.
input:
Tally the toxicology element of the 4th atom of each molecule that was carcinogenic.
CREATE TABLE `atom` (

  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'identifying the molecule to which the atom belongs; commonsense evidence:
TRXXX_i represents ith atom of molecule TRXXX',
  `element` TEXT COMMENT 'the element of the toxicology;  cl: chlorine

);

- this molecule is not / compound carcinogenic',
  `label` TEXT COMMENT 'whether this molecule is carcinogenic or not'
);
chosen:
SELECT DISTINCT
  `T1`.`element`
FROM `atom` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `molecule` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`molecule_id` = `T2`.`molecule_id`
WHERE
  `T2`.`label` = '+'
  AND SUBSTR(`T1`.`atom_id`, -1) = '4'
  AND LENGTH(`T1`.`atom_id`) = 7

SELECT

    `T1`.`element`,

  FROM `atom` AS `T1`
  INNER JOIN `molecule` AS `T2`
    ON `T1`.`molecule_id` = `T2`.`molecule_id`

    `T2`.`label` = '+'

WHERE

  `T`.`element`

CREATE TABLE `atom` (
  `atom_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the unique id of atoms',
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'identifying the molecule to which the atom belongs; commonsense evidence:
TRXXX_i represents ith atom of molecule TRXXX',
  `element` TEXT COMMENT 'the element of the toxicology;  cl: chlorine
 c: carbon
 h: hydrogen
 o: oxygen
 s: sulfur
 n: nitrogen
 p: phosphorus
 na: sodium
 br: bromine
 f: fluorine
 i: iodine
 sn: Tin
 pb: lead
 te: tellurium
 ca: Calcium'
);
CREATE TABLE `bond` (
  `bond_id` TEXT COMMENT 'unique id representing bonds; TRxxx_A1_A2:
TRXXX refers to which molecule
A1 and A2 refers to which atom',
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'identifying the molecule in which the bond appears',
  `bond_type` TEXT COMMENT 'type of the bond; commonsense evidence:
-: single bond
=: double bond
#: triple bond'
);
CREATE TABLE `connected` (
  `atom_id` TEXT COMMENT 'id of the first atom',
  `atom_id2` TEXT COMMENT 'id of the second atom',
  `bond_id` TEXT COMMENT 'bond id representing bond between two atoms'
);
CREATE TABLE `molecule` (
  `molecule_id` TEXT COMMENT 'unique id of molecule; "+" --> this molecule / compound is carcinogenic
- this molecule is not / compound carcinogenic',
  `label` TEXT COMMENT 'whether this molecule is carcinogenic or not'
);
chosen:
SELECT
  `T`.`molecule_id`
FROM (
  SELECT
    `T1`.`molecule_id`,
    COUNT(`T2`.`atom_id`)
  FROM `molecule` AS `T1`
  INNER JOIN `atom` AS `T2`
    ON `T1`.`molecule_id` = `T2`.`molecule_id`
  WHERE
    `T1`.`label` = '-'
  GROUP BY
    `T1`.`molecule_id`
  HAVING
    COUNT(`T2`.`atom_id`) > 5
) AS `t`
rejected:
SELECT DISTINCT
  `T1`.`molecule_id`
FROM `molecule` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `atom` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`molecule_id` = `T2`.`molecule_id`
WHERE
  `T1`.`label` = '-' AND NOT EXISTS (
    SELECT
      *
    FROM `bond`
    WHERE
      `molecule_id` = `T1`.`molecule_id` AND `bond_type` = '#'
  )
GROUP BY
  `T1`.`molecule_id`
HAVING
  COUNT(`T2`.`atom_id`) > 5

  `NumTstTakr` BIGINT COMMENT 'Number of Test Takers in this school; number of test takers in each school',
  `AvgScrRead` BIGINT COMMENT 'average scores in Reading; average scores in Reading',
  `AvgScrMath` BIGINT COMMENT 'average scores in Math; average scores in Math',
  `AvgScrWrite` BIGINT COMMENT 'average scores in writing; average scores in writing',
  `NumGE1500` BIGINT COMMENT 'Number of Test Takers Whose Total SAT Scores Are Greater or Equal to 1500; Number of Test Takers Whose Total SAT Scores Are Greater or Equal to 1500

commonsense evidence:

Excellence Rate = NumGE1500 / NumTstTakr'
);
CREATE TABLE `schools` (
  `CDSCode` TEXT COMMENT 'CDSCode',
  `NCESDist` TEXT COMMENT 'This field represents the 7-digit National Center for Educational Statistics (NCES) school district identification number. The first 2 digits identify the state and the last 5 digits identify the school district. Combined, they make a unique 7-digit ID for each school district.',
  `NCESSchool` TEXT COMMENT 'This field represents the 5-digit NCES school identification number. The NCESSchool combined with the NCESDist form a unique 12-digit ID for each school.',
  `StatusType` TEXT COMMENT 'This field identifies the status of the district.; Definitions of the valid status types are listed below:
·       Active: The district is in operation and providing instructional services.
·       Closed: The district is not in operation and no longer providing instructional services.
·       Merged: The district has combined with another district or districts.
·       Pending: The district has not opened for operation and instructional services yet, but plans to open within the next 9–12 months.',
  `County` TEXT COMMENT 'County name',
  `District` TEXT COMMENT 'District',
  `School` TEXT COMMENT 'School',
  `Street` TEXT COMMENT 'Street',
  `StreetAbr` TEXT COMMENT 'The abbreviated street address of the school, district, or administrative authority’s physical location.; The abbreviated street address of the school, district, or administrative authority’s physical location. Note: Some records (primarily records of closed or retired schools) may not have data in this field.',
  `City` TEXT COMMENT 'City',
  `Zip` TEXT COMMENT 'Zip',
  `State` TEXT COMMENT 'State',
  `MailStreet` TEXT COMMENT 'MailStreet; The unabbreviated mailing address of the school, district, or administrative authority. Note: 1) Some entities (primarily closed or retired schools) may not have data in this field; 2) Many active entities have not provided a mailing street address. For your convenience we have filled the unpopulated MailStreet cells with Street data.',
  `MailStrAbr` TEXT COMMENT 'the abbreviated mailing street address of the school, district, or administrative authority.Note: Many active entities have not provided a mailing street address. For your convenience we have filled the unpopulated MailStrAbr cells with StreetAbr data.',
  `MailCity` TEXT COMMENT 'The city associated with the mailing address of the school, district, or administrative authority. Note: Many entities have not provided a mailing address city. For your convenience we have filled the unpopulated MailCity cells with City data.',
  `MailZip` TEXT COMMENT 'The zip code associated with the mailing address of the school, district, or administrative authority. Note: Many entities have not provided a mailing address zip code. For your convenience we have filled the unpopulated MailZip cells with Zip data.',
  `MailState` TEXT COMMENT 'The state within the mailing address. For your convenience we have filled the unpopulated MailState cells with State data.',
  `Phone` TEXT COMMENT 'Phone',
  `Ext` TEXT COMMENT 'The phone number extension of the school, district, or administrative authority.; The phone number extension of the school, district, or administrative authority.',
  `Website` TEXT COMMENT 'The website address of the school, district, or administrative authority.; The website address of the school, district, or administrative authority.',
  `OpenDate` TEXT COMMENT 'The date the school opened.',
  `ClosedDate` TEXT COMMENT 'The date the school closed.',
  `Charter` BIGINT COMMENT 'This field identifies a charter school.; The field is coded as follows:

·       1 = The school is a charter

·       0 = The school is not a charter',
  `CharterNum` TEXT COMMENT 'The charter school number,; 4-digit number assigned to a charter school.',
  `FundingType` TEXT COMMENT 'Indicates the charter school funding type; Values are as follows:

·       Not in CS (California School) funding model

·       Locally funded

·       Directly funded',
  `DOC` TEXT COMMENT 'District Ownership Code; The District Ownership Code (DOC) is the numeric code used to identify the category of the Administrative Authority.
•       00 - County Office of Education
•       02 – State Board of Education
•       03 – Statewide Benefit Charter
•       31 – State Special Schools
•       34 – Non-school Location*
•       52 – Elementary School District
•       54 – Unified School District
•       56 – High School District
•       98 – Regional Occupational Center/Program (ROC/P)
commonsense evidence:
*Only the California Education Authority has been included in the non-school location category.',
  `DOCType` TEXT COMMENT 'The District Ownership Code Type is the text description of the DOC category.; (See text values in DOC field description above)',
  `SOC` TEXT COMMENT 'The School Ownership Code is a numeric code used to identify the type of school.; •      08 - Preschool      
•       09 – Special Education Schools (Public)
•      11 – Youth Authority Facilities (CEA)
•       13 – Opportunity Schools
•       14 – Juvenile Court Schools
•       15 – Other County or District Programs
•       31 – State Special Schools
•       60 – Elementary School (Public)
•       61 – Elementary School in 1 School District (Public)
•       62 – Intermediate/Middle Schools (Public)
•       63 – Alternative Schools of Choice
•       64 – Junior High Schools (Public)
•       65 – K-12 Schools (Public)
•       66 – High Schools (Public)
•       67 – High Schools in 1 School District (Public)
•       68 – Continuation High Schools
•       69 – District Community Day Schools
•       70 – Adult Education Centers
•       98 – Regional Occupational Center/Program (ROC/P)',
  `SOCType` TEXT COMMENT 'The School Ownership Code Type is the text description of the type of school.; The School Ownership Code Type is the text description of the type of school.',
  `EdOpsCode` TEXT COMMENT 'The Education Option Code is a short text description of the type of education offered.; •      ALTSOC – Alternative School of Choice
•      COMM – County Community School
•       COMMDAY – Community Day School
•       CON – Continuation School
•       JUV – Juvenile Court School
•       OPP – Opportunity School
•       YTH – Youth Authority School
•       SSS – State Special School
•       SPEC – Special Education School
•       TRAD – Traditional
•       ROP – Regional Occupational Program
•       HOMHOS – Home and Hospital
•       SPECON – District Consortia Special Education School',
  `EdOpsName` TEXT COMMENT 'Educational Option Name; The Educational Option Name is the long text description of the type of education being offered.',
  `EILCode` TEXT COMMENT 'The Educational Instruction Level Code is a short text description of the institutions type relative to the grade range served.; •       A – Adult
•       ELEM – Elementary
•       ELEMHIGH – Elementary-High Combination
•       HS – High School
•       INTMIDJR – Intermediate/Middle/Junior High
•       PS – Preschool
•       UG – Ungraded',
  `EILName` TEXT COMMENT 'The Educational Instruction Level Name is the long text description of the institution’s type relative to the grade range served.; The Educational Instruction Level Name is the long text description of the institution’s type relative to the grade range served.',
  `GSoffered` TEXT COMMENT 'The grade span offered is the lowest grade and the highest grade offered or supported by the school, district, or administrative authority. This field might differ from the grade span served as reported in the most recent certified California Longitudinal Pupil Achievement (CALPADS) Fall 1 data collection.; For example XYZ School might display the following data:

GSoffered = P–Adult

GSserved = K–12',
  `GSserved` TEXT COMMENT 'It is the lowest grade and the highest grade of student enrollment as reported in the most recent certified CALPADS Fall 1 data collection. Only K–12 enrollment is reported through CALPADS. This field may differ from the grade span offered.; commonsense evidence:

1.     Only K–12 enrollment is reported through CALPADS

2.     Note: Special programs at independent study, alternative education, and special education schools will often exceed the typical grade span for schools of that type',
  `Virtual` TEXT COMMENT 'This field identifies the type of virtual instruction offered by the school. Virtual instruction is instruction in which students and teachers are separated by time and/or location, and interaction occurs via computers and/or telecommunications technologies.; The field is coded as follows:

·       F = Exclusively Virtual – The school has no physical building where students meet with each other or with teachers, all instruction is virtual.

·       V = Primarily Virtual – The school focuses on a systematic program of virtual instruction but includes some physical meetings among students or with teachers.

·       C = Primarily Classroom – The school offers virtual courses but virtual instruction is not the primary means of instruction.

·       N = Not Virtual – The school does not offer any virtual instruction.

·       P = Partial Virtual – The school offers some, but not all, instruction through virtual instruction. Note: This value was retired and replaced with the Primarily Virtual and Primarily Classroom values beginning with the 2016–17 school year.',
  `Magnet` BIGINT COMMENT 'This field identifies whether a school is a magnet school and/or provides a magnet program.; The field is coded as follows:

·       1 = Magnet - The school is a magnet school and/or offers a magnet program.

·       0 = Not Magnet - The school is not a magnet school and/or does not offer a magnet program.

commonsense evidence:

Note: Preschools and adult education centers do not contain a magnet school indicator.',
  `Latitude` DOUBLE COMMENT 'The angular distance (expressed in degrees) between the location of the school, district, or administrative authority and the equator measured north to south.; The angular distance (expressed in degrees) between the location of the school, district, or administrative authority and the equator measured north to south.',
  `Longitude` DOUBLE COMMENT 'The angular distance (expressed in degrees) between the location of the school, district, or administrative authority and the prime meridian (Greenwich, England) measured from west to east.; The angular distance (expressed in degrees) between the location of the school, district, or administrative authority and the prime meridian (Greenwich, England) measured from west to east.',
  `AdmFName1` TEXT COMMENT 'administrators first name; The superintendent’s or principal’s first name.

commonsense evidence:

Only active and pending districts and schools will display administrator information, if applicable.',
  `AdmLName1` TEXT COMMENT 'administrators last name; The superintendent’s or principal’s last name.

commonsense evidence:
Only active and pending districts and schools will display administrator information, if applicable.',
  `AdmEmail1` TEXT COMMENT 'administrators email address; The superintendent’s or principal’s email address.

commonsense evidence:

Only active and pending districts and schools will display administrator information, if applicable.',
  `AdmFName2` TEXT COMMENT 'SAME as 1',
  `AdmLName2` TEXT,
  `AdmEmail2` TEXT,
  `AdmFName3` TEXT COMMENT 'not useful',
  `AdmLName3` TEXT COMMENT 'not useful',
  `AdmEmail3` TEXT COMMENT 'not useful',
  `LastUpdate` TEXT COMMENT 'when is this record updated last time'
);
chosen: SELECT  COUNT(DISTINCT `T2`.`School`) FROM `satscores` AS `T1` INNER JOIN `schools` AS `T2`  ON `T1`.`cds` = `T2`.`CDSCode` WHERE  `T2`.`Virtual` = 'F' AND `T1`.`AvgScrMath` > 400
rejected:
SELECT
  COUNT(`T1`.`School`)
FROM `schools` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `satscores` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`cds`
WHERE
  `T2`.`AvgScrMath` > 400 AND `T1`.`Virtual` = 'F'

  `T2`.`CDSCode`
FROM `schools` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `frpm` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`CDSCode`

  `T2`.`Enrollment (K-12)` + `T2`.`Enrollment (Ages 5-17)` > 500

  )

chosen:
SELECT
  MAX(
    CAST(`T1`.`Free Meal Count (Ages 5-17)` AS DOUBLE) / `T1`.`Enrollment (Ages 5-17)`
  )
FROM `frpm` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `satscores` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`cds`
WHERE
  CAST(`T2`.`NumGE1500` AS DOUBLE) / `T2`.`NumTstTakr` > 0.3
rejected:

  )
FROM `frpm` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `satscores` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`cds`
WHERE
  CAST(`T2`.`NumGE1500` AS DOUBLE) / `T2`.`NumTstTakr` > 0.3

SELECT
  `CharterNum`,
  `AvgScrWrite`,
  RANK() OVER (ORDER BY `AvgScrWrite` DESC) AS `WritingScoreRank`
FROM `schools` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `satscores` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`cds`
WHERE
  `T2`.`AvgScrWrite` > 499 AND NOT `CharterNum` IS NULL
rejected:

  `AvgScrWrite`
FROM `schools` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `satscores` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`cds`
WHERE
  `Charter` = 1 AND `AvgScrWrite` > 499
ORDER BY
  `AvgScrWrite` DESC

  CAST(`T2`.`Enrollment (K-12)` AS DOUBLE) - CAST(`T2`.`Enrollment (Ages 5-17)` AS DOUBLE) > 30

SELECT
  `T1`.`sname`,
  `T2`.`Charter Funding Type`
FROM `satscores` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `frpm` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`cds` = `T2`.`CDSCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`District Name` LIKE 'Riverside%'
GROUP BY
  `T1`.`sname`,
  `T2`.`Charter Funding Type`
HAVING
  CAST(SUM(`T1`.`AvgScrMath`) AS DOUBLE) / COUNT(`T1`.`cds`) > 400
rejected:
SELECT DISTINCT
  `T1`.`School`,
  `T2`.`Charter Funding Type`
FROM `frpm` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `schools` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`CDSCode`
INNER JOIN `satscores` AS `T3`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T3`.`cds`
WHERE
  `T2`.`County` = 'Riverside' AND `T3`.`AvgScrMath` > 400

chosen:
SELECT
  `T2`.`School`,
  `T2`.`DOC`
FROM `frpm` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `schools` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`CDSCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`FundingType` = 'Locally funded'
  AND (
    `T1`.`Enrollment (K-12)` - `T1`.`Enrollment (Ages 5-17)`
  ) > (
    SELECT
      AVG(`T3`.`Enrollment (K-12)` - `T3`.`Enrollment (Ages 5-17)`)
    FROM `frpm` AS `T3`
    INNER JOIN `schools` AS `T4`
      ON `T3`.`CDSCode` = `T4`.`CDSCode`
    WHERE
      `T4`.`FundingType` = 'Locally funded'
  )
rejected:
SELECT
  `T1`.`School`,
  `T1`.`DOC`
FROM `schools` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `frpm` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`CDSCode`
WHERE
  `T1`.`FundingType` = 'Locally funded'
  AND (
    CAST(`T2`.`Enrollment (K-12)` AS DOUBLE) - CAST(`T2`.`Enrollment (Ages 5-17)` AS DOUBLE)
  ) > (
    SELECT
      AVG(CAST(`Enrollment (K-12)` AS DOUBLE) - CAST(`Enrollment (Ages 5-17)` AS DOUBLE))
    FROM `frpm`
    WHERE
      `Enrollment (K-12)` IS NOT NULL
      AND `Enrollment (Ages 5-17)` IS NOT NULL
  )

Virtual instruction is instruction in which students and teachers are separated by time and/or location, and interaction occurs via computers and/or telecommunications technologies.; The field is coded as follows:

·       F = Exclusively Virtual – The school has no physical building where students meet with each other or with teachers, all instruction is virtual.

·       V = Primarily Virtual – The school focuses on a systematic program of virtual instruction but includes some physical meetings among students or with teachers.

·       C = Primarily Classroom – The school offers virtual courses but virtual instruction is not the primary means of instruction.

·       N = Not Virtual – The school does not offer any virtual instruction.

·       P = Partial Virtual – The school offers some, but not all, instruction through virtual instruction. Note: This value was retired and replaced with the Primarily Virtual and Primarily Classroom values beginning with the 2016–17 school year.',
  `Magnet` BIGINT COMMENT 'This field identifies whether a school is a magnet school and/or provides a magnet program.; The field is coded as follows:

chosen:
SELECT
  CAST(`T1`.`FRPM Count (K-12)` AS DOUBLE) / `T1`.`Enrollment (K-12)`
FROM `frpm` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `schools` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`CDSCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`SOC` = 66
ORDER BY
  `T1`.`FRPM Count (K-12)` DESC
LIMIT 5

chosen: SELECT  School FROM ( SELECT T2.School, T1.AvgScrRead, RANK() OVER (PARTITION BY T2.County ORDER BY T1.AvgScrRead DESC) AS rnk FROM satscores AS T1 INNER JOIN schools AS T2 ON T1.cds = T2.CDSCode WHERE T2.Virtual = 'F') ranked_schools WHERE rnk <= 5
rejected:
SELECT
  `T2`.`School`
FROM `satscores` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `schools` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`cds` = `T2`.`CDSCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`Virtual` = 'F' AND `T2`.`County` IN (
    SELECT
      `County`
    FROM (
      SELECT
        `County`,
        ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY AVG(`AvgScrRead`) DESC) AS `rn`
      FROM `satscores` AS `T1`
      INNER JOIN `schools` AS `T2`
        ON `T1`.`cds` = `T2`.`CDSCode`
      WHERE
        `T2`.`Virtual` = 'F'
      GROUP BY
        `County`
    ) AS `t`
    WHERE
      `rn` <= 5
  )

  `T2`.`School`
FROM `frpm` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `schools` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`CDSCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`DOC` = 31
ORDER BY
  `T1`.`Enrollment (K-12)` DESC
LIMIT 1
rejected:

  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`CDSCode`

  `T1`.`SOC` = 31 AND `T1`.`GSserved` = 'K-12'
GROUP BY
  `T1`.`School`
ORDER BY
  SUM(`T2`.`Enrollment (K-12)`) DESC
LIMIT 1

SELECT
  COUNT(`T2`.`School`)
FROM `frpm` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `schools` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`CDSCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`County` = 'Los Angeles'
  AND `T2`.`Charter` = 0
  AND CAST(`T1`.`Free Meal Count (K-12)` AS DOUBLE) * 100 / `T1`.`Enrollment (K-12)` < 0.18

  AND `T2`.`Charter` = 0

SELECT
  `T2`.`City`,
  COUNT(`T2`.`CDSCode`)
FROM `frpm` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `schools` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`CDSCode` = `T2`.`CDSCode`
WHERE
  `T2`.`Magnet` = 1
  AND `T2`.`GSoffered` = 'K-8'
  AND `T1`.`NSLP Provision Status` = 'Multiple Provision Types'
GROUP BY
  `T2`.`City`
rejected:

WHERE
  `T1`.`Magnet` = 1 AND `T2`.`Low Grade` = 'K' AND `T2`.`High Grade` = '8'

instruction: You are an expert data analyst. Please write a MySQL query that satisfies the requirement below.
input:
How many accounts who choose issuance after transaction are staying in East Bohemia region?
CREATE TABLE `account` (
  `account_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the account',
  `district_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'location of branch',
  `frequency` TEXT COMMENT 'frequency of the acount',
  `date` TEXT COMMENT 'the creation date of the account; in the form YYMMDD'
);
CREATE TABLE `card` (
  `card_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'id number of credit card',
  `disp_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'disposition id',
  `type` TEXT COMMENT 'type of credit card; "junior": junior class of credit card; 
"classic": standard class of credit card; 
"gold": high-level credit card',
  `issued` TEXT COMMENT 'the date when the credit card issued; in the form YYMMDD'
);
CREATE TABLE `client` (
  `client_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique number',
  `gender` TEXT COMMENT 'F：female 
M：male',
  `birth_date` TEXT COMMENT 'birth date',
  `district_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'location of branch'
);
CREATE TABLE `disp` (
  `disp_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'unique number of identifying this row of record',
  `client_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'id number of client',
  `account_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'id number of account',
  `type` TEXT COMMENT 'type of disposition; "OWNER" : "USER" : "DISPONENT"
commonsense evidence:
the account can only have the right to issue permanent orders or apply for loans'
);
CREATE TABLE `district` (
  `district_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'location of branch',
  `A2` TEXT COMMENT 'district_name',
  `A3` TEXT COMMENT 'region',
  `A4` TEXT,
  `A5` TEXT COMMENT 'municipality < district < region',
  `A6` TEXT COMMENT 'municipality < district < region',
  `A7` TEXT COMMENT 'municipality < district < region',
  `A8` BIGINT COMMENT 'municipality < district < region',
  `A9` BIGINT COMMENT 'not useful',
  `A10` DOUBLE COMMENT 'ratio of urban inhabitants',
  `A11` BIGINT COMMENT 'average salary',
  `A12` DOUBLE COMMENT 'unemployment rate 1995',
  `A13` DOUBLE COMMENT 'unemployment rate 1996',
  `A14` BIGINT COMMENT 'no. of entrepreneurs per 1000 inhabitants',
  `A15` BIGINT COMMENT 'no. of committed crimes 1995',
  `A16` BIGINT COMMENT 'no. of committed crimes 1996'
);
CREATE TABLE `loan` (
  `loan_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id number identifying the loan data',
  `account_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id number identifying the account',
  `date` TEXT COMMENT 'the date when the loan is approved',
  `amount` BIGINT COMMENT 'approved amount; unit：US dollar',
  `duration` BIGINT COMMENT 'loan duration; unit：month',
  `payments` DOUBLE COMMENT 'monthly payments; unit：month',
  `status` TEXT COMMENT 'repayment status; A stands for contract finished, no problems;
B stands for contract finished, loan not paid;
C stands for running contract, OK so far;
D stands for running contract, client in debt'
);
CREATE TABLE `order` (
  `order_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'identifying the unique order',
  `account_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'id number of account',
  `bank_to` TEXT COMMENT 'bank of the recipient',
  `account_to` BIGINT COMMENT 'account of the recipient; each bank has unique two-letter code',
  `amount` DOUBLE COMMENT 'debited amount',
  `k_symbol` TEXT COMMENT 'purpose of the payment; "POJISTNE" stands for insurance payment
"SIPO" stands for household payment
"LEASING" stands for leasing
"UVER" stands for loan payment'
);
CREATE TABLE `trans` (
  `trans_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'transaction id',
  `account_id` BIGINT,
  `date` TEXT COMMENT 'date of transaction',
  `type` TEXT COMMENT '+/- transaction; "PRIJEM" stands for credit
"VYDAJ" stands for withdrawal',
  `operation` TEXT COMMENT 'mode of transaction; "VYBER KARTOU": credit card withdrawal
"VKLAD": credit in cash
"PREVOD Z UCTU" :collection from another bank
"VYBER": withdrawal in cash
"PREVOD NA UCET": remittance to another bank',
  `amount` BIGINT COMMENT 'amount of money; Unit：USD',
  `balance` BIGINT COMMENT 'balance after transaction; Unit：USD',
  `k_symbol` TEXT COMMENT '"POJISTNE": stands for insurrance payment
"SLUZBY": stands for payment for statement
"UROK": stands for interest credited
"SANKC. UROK": sanction interest if negative balance
"SIPO": stands for household
"DUCHOD": stands for old-age pension
"UVER": stands for loan payment',
  `bank` TEXT COMMENT 'each bank has unique two-letter code',
  `account` BIGINT
);
chosen:
SELECT
  COUNT(`T2`.`account_id`)
FROM `district` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `account` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`district_id` = `T2`.`district_id`
WHERE
  `T1`.`A3` = 'east Bohemia' AND `T2`.`frequency` = 'POPLATEK PO OBRATU'
rejected:
SELECT
  COUNT(`T1`.`account_id`)
FROM `account` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `district` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`district_id` = `T2`.`district_id`
WHERE
  `T1`.`frequency` = 'POPLATEK PO OBRATU' AND `T2`.`A3` = 'east Bohemia'

SELECT
  `T1`.`account_id`,
  (
    SELECT
      MAX(`A11`) - MIN(`A11`)
    FROM `district`
  )
FROM `account` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `district` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`district_id` = `T2`.`district_id`
INNER JOIN `disp` AS `T3`
  ON `T1`.`account_id` = `T3`.`account_id`
INNER JOIN `client` AS `T4`
  ON `T3`.`client_id` = `T4`.`client_id`
WHERE
  `T2`.`district_id` = (
    SELECT
      `district_id`
    FROM `client`
    WHERE
      `gender` = 'F'
    ORDER BY
      `birth_date` ASC
    LIMIT 1
  )
ORDER BY
  `T2`.`A11` DESC
LIMIT 1

  ON `T1`.`client_id` = `T3`.`client_id`
WHERE
  `T3`.`gender` = 'F'
GROUP BY
  `T1`.`account_id`

FROM `account` AS `T1`

INNER JOIN `client` AS `T3`
  ON `T2`.`client_id` = `T3`.`client_id`
INNER JOIN `district` AS `T4`
  ON `T4`.`district_id` = `T1`.`district_id`
WHERE
  `T2`.`client_id` = (
    SELECT
      `client_id`
    FROM `client`
    ORDER BY
      `birth_date` DESC

  )
GROUP BY
  `T4`.`A11`,
  `T1`.`account_id`

WHERE
  `T1`.`A11` = (
    SELECT
      MAX(`A11`)
    FROM `district`
  )
ORDER BY
  `T2`.`client_id` ASC
LIMIT 1

"VYDAJ" stands for withdrawal',

"VKLAD": credit in cash
"PREVOD Z UCTU" :collection from another bank

SELECT
  CAST((
    SUM(CASE WHEN `T3`.`date` = '1998-12-27' THEN `T3`.`balance` ELSE 0 END) - SUM(CASE WHEN `T3`.`date` = '1993-03-22' THEN `T3`.`balance` ELSE 0 END)
  ) AS DOUBLE) * 100 / SUM(CASE WHEN `T3`.`date` = '1993-03-22' THEN `T3`.`balance` ELSE 0 END)
FROM `loan` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `account` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`account_id` = `T2`.`account_id`
INNER JOIN `trans` AS `T3`
  ON `T3`.`account_id` = `T2`.`account_id`
WHERE
  `T1`.`date` = '1993-07-05'

INNER JOIN `loan` AS `T3`
  ON `T1`.`account_id` = `T3`.`account_id`
WHERE
  `T3`.`date` = '1993-07-05' AND `T2`.`date` = '1998-12-27'

  `A7` TEXT COMMENT 'municipality < district < region',
  `A8` BIGINT COMMENT 'municipality < district < region',
  `A9` BIGINT COMMENT 'not useful',
  `A10` DOUBLE COMMENT 'ratio of urban inhabitants',
  `A11` BIGINT COMMENT 'average salary',
  `A12` DOUBLE COMMENT 'unemployment rate 1995',
  `A13` DOUBLE COMMENT 'unemployment rate 1996',
  `A14` BIGINT COMMENT 'no. of entrepreneurs per 1000 inhabitants',
  `A15` BIGINT COMMENT 'no. of committed crimes 1995',
  `A16` BIGINT COMMENT 'no. of committed crimes 1996'
);
CREATE TABLE `loan` (
  `loan_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id number identifying the loan data',
  `account_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id number identifying the account',
  `date` TEXT COMMENT 'the date when the loan is approved',

);

"SIPO" stands for household payment

);
CREATE TABLE `trans` (
  `trans_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'transaction id',
  `account_id` BIGINT,
  `date` TEXT COMMENT 'date of transaction',

"VYDAJ" stands for withdrawal',
  `operation` TEXT COMMENT 'mode of transaction; "VYBER KARTOU": credit card withdrawal
"VKLAD": credit in cash
"PREVOD Z UCTU" :collection from another bank
"VYBER": withdrawal in cash
"PREVOD NA UCET": remittance to another bank',
  `amount` BIGINT COMMENT 'amount of money; Unit：USD',
  `balance` BIGINT COMMENT 'balance after transaction; Unit：USD',
  `k_symbol` TEXT COMMENT '"POJISTNE": stands for insurrance payment
"SLUZBY": stands for payment for statement
"UROK": stands for interest credited
"SANKC. UROK": sanction interest if negative balance
"SIPO": stands for household
"DUCHOD": stands for old-age pension
"UVER": stands for loan payment',
  `bank` TEXT COMMENT 'each bank has unique two-letter code',
  `account` BIGINT
);
chosen:
SELECT
  CAST((
    SUM(
      CASE
        WHEN DATE_FORMAT(CAST(`T1`.`date` AS DATETIME), '%Y') = '1997'
        THEN `T1`.`amount`
        ELSE 0
      END
    ) - SUM(
      CASE
        WHEN DATE_FORMAT(CAST(`T1`.`date` AS DATETIME), '%Y') = '1996'
        THEN `T1`.`amount`
        ELSE 0
      END
    )
  ) AS DOUBLE) * 100 / SUM(
    CASE
      WHEN DATE_FORMAT(CAST(`T1`.`date` AS DATETIME), '%Y') = '1996'
      THEN `T1`.`amount`
      ELSE 0
    END
  )
FROM `loan` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `account` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`account_id` = `T2`.`account_id`
INNER JOIN `disp` AS `T3`
  ON `T3`.`account_id` = `T2`.`account_id`
INNER JOIN `client` AS `T4`
  ON `T4`.`client_id` = `T3`.`client_id`
WHERE
  `T4`.`gender` = 'M' AND `T3`.`type` = 'OWNER'
rejected:
SELECT
  CAST(SUM(CASE WHEN DATE_FORMAT(CAST(`T1`.`date` AS DATETIME), '%Y') = '1997' THEN `T1`.`amount` ELSE 0 END) AS DOUBLE) * 100 / SUM(CASE WHEN DATE_FORMAT(CAST(`T1`.`date` AS DATETIME), '%Y') = '1996' THEN `T1`.`amount` ELSE 0 END)
FROM `loan` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `account` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`account_id` = `T2`.`account_id`
INNER JOIN `disp` AS `T3`
  ON `T2`.`account_id` = `T3`.`account_id`
INNER JOIN `client` AS `T4`
  ON `T3`.`client_id` = `T4`.`client_id`
WHERE
  `T4`.`gender` = 'M'
